node.title: Subsidies
node.description: The definition of subsidies includes all direct payments to the farmers by national or supranational authorities, none of which are involved in agri-environmental schemes.

node.title: Gross Value of Production (GVP)
node.description: The goal of this indicator is to compare the production value of agriculture per unit of area and the importance of the agricultural sector to the national economy.

node.title: Farm Profits
node.description: This indicator shows the competitiveness/profitability of farmers and farming systems respectively.

node.title: Variable Costs
node.description: This indicator considers costs (in Euro) of seed, fertilization, crop protection products, soil preparation, and machinery.

node.title: Fixed Costs
node.description: This indicator considers costs (in Euro) of labor, deprecation, maintenance/general repair of machinery, buildings, credits, insurance costs, and investment.

node.title: Soil Carbon balance
node.description: The calculation of this indicator assesses factors such as soil production by plants and the subsequent mineralization of plant waste in proportion to the fruits received from the field.

node.title: Nutrients Balance
node.description: Amount of fertilization, properties of the cropped soils, mineralization processes – all determined by soil properties.

node.title: Compaction
node.description: Soil compaction is the term used to indicate the deterioration of the soil structure by mechanical pressure, predominantly from agricultural practices.

node.title: Erosion
node.description: Five major factors are used to calculate the soil loss for a given site. Each factor is the numerical estimate of a specific condition that affects the severity of soil erosion at a particular location.

node.title: State Indicator
node.description: The higher the number of endangered species is, the more vulnerable the ecosystem can be considered.

node.title: Agri-Environment Schemes
node.description: Farmers may receive funding for services that promote elements of biodiversity by various Agri-Environment Schemes, e.g. flower strips, precise timing of mowing or support for traditional farming practices.

node.title: Protected Areas
node.description: The availability of protected (often, but not always uncropped) zones is a very important protection measure that promotes biodiversity in general, in areas inside and outside the protection zones.

node.title: Ecotoxicity
node.description: The ecotoxicity of plant protection products has the potential to influence biodiversity. These side-effects are dependent on the product-specific ecotoxicity profile of each compound, which are tested in laboratory, semi-field and field conditions for registration purposes.

node.title: Farming Intensity
node.description: This indicator is evaluated through an assessment of the farming related “actions” occurring in the field. These include plowing, mechanical treatments, fertilization, crop protection and have an important impact on primary diversity in ecosystems.

node.title: Nitrogen Surplus
node.description: The availability of nitrogen fertilizer is a key indicator for biodiversity in cultural landscapes and is calculated within this indicator-algorithm.

node.title: Potential for Intermixing
node.description: This refers to crop species that have the potential to intermix with the natural vegetation. The intermixing potential is crop-specific and driven by several parameters.

node.title: Crop Rotation
node.description: This indicator shows how to enhance biodiversity by having proper crop rotation. It factors the number of elements in crop rotation within two years.

node.title: Water Use
node.description: This indicator category determines the water footprint. This is calculated from the consumption of water in the life cycle of products and processes within the food and feed value chain.

node.title: Land Use
node.description: Agricultural production specifically relies on land as a crucial resource. The land indicator category in AgBalance takes into account the amount of land needed for a production system and the suitability of that land for eco-systems.

node.title: Energy Consumption
node.description: The use of primary energy in a product system should be as efficient as possible, mitigating against carbon emissions and preserving resources. This category takes into account the consumption of renewable and non-renewable energy in the life cycle of products and processes within the food and feed value chain.

node.title: Emissions
node.description: Calculates Air emissions, Greenhouse Gases, Acidification Potential, Ozone depletion potential, Photochemical Oxidation Creation potential, Water emissions, Solid Waste.

node.title: Resource Consumption
node.description: The depletion of non-renewable resources is a risk to our society. This not only relates to fossil resources but also to all kinds of other resources, e.g., rare metals/elements used in machinery or electronics.

node.title: Eco-Toxicity Potential
node.description: This category includes the assessed eco-toxicity potential of the production system. Examples are risk of spills, explosions, hazardous irradiation etc.

node.title: Wages
node.description: Wages/salaries of agricultural workers as per customer benefit.

node.title: Professional Training
node.description: Shows the level of education that leads to successful products.

node.title: Association Membership
node.description: The percentage of farmers/workers that are members of agricultural associations; ratio of number of different associations per farmer/worker.

node.title: Wages and Salaries, prechain
node.description: This indicator takes the wages and salaries in the prechain into account. Higher wages show an increased social security.

node.title: Toxicity Potential
node.description: This reflects potential human health impacts on employees or farmers. The assessment takes into account the toxicity potential of materials, which are part of the studied system and a simple estimate of the exposure risk.

node.title: Risk Potential
node.description: The indicator evaluates potential of working accidents and/or occupational Diseases.

node.title: Strikes and Lockouts
node.description: A low number of strikes and lockouts indicates a higher satisfaction of workers. Freedom to assembly and guarantee of human rights is taken as granted.

node.title: Residues in Feed & Food
node.description: This indicator describes the percentage of samples of food that exceed official Maximum Residue Limits (MRLs). It is expressed in terms of exceedences.

node.title: Unauthorized/Unlabeled GMO
node.description: The occurrence of food products containing unauthorized or unlabeled genetically modified organisms (GMO).

node.title: Toxicity Potential
node.description: Consumers can sometimes be confronted with toxic substances. It is a measure of risks to human health.

node.title: Functional Product Characteristics
node.description: Considers functionality and possible risks of technologies and/or products.

node.title: Access to Land
node.description: This indicator calculates the percentage of the leased land – within the agricultural area – that is used for the benefit of the customer, multiplied by the leasing rent.

node.title: Number of Employees
node.description: This indicator shows how a substance contributes to the welfare of a national region. This indicator therefore calculates the number of employed people per customer benefit.

node.title: Gender Equality
node.description: The deviation of the percentage of women who are farm managers in the agricultural sector from the societal percentage of the female population.

node.title: Integration
node.description: Employment of people with (severe) disabilities.

node.title: Qualified Employees
node.description: Working time of all employees excluded unskilled workers associated with the product system.

node.title: Employees
node.description: Working time of all employees associated with the product system.

node.title: Part Time workers
node.description: A higher level of flexible working schemes associated with the production system is seen as more desirable.

node.title: Family Support
node.description: ncludes parental leave and other bonus for marriage and children, benefits for diseases, birth, death etc. A higher value of family support is associated with a more desirable situation.

node.title: Developing Countries Import
node.description: Trade balance relating to trade with developing countries.

node.title: Fair Trade Benefits
node.description: Producer Prices, including price advantages and premiums paid through the Fair Trade program.

node.title: Foreign Direct Investment
node.description: Focus on developing countries – from the perspective of the country under study. A higher value represents a more desirable situation.

node.title: Child Labour
node.description: Observes child labor across all life-cycle steps. This takes into account the degree to which child labor is associated with the production of certain products that are part of the studied system.

node.title: Trainees
node.description: Shows how the next generation is involved in the industrial processes and what will help support their education more effectively. This indicator assesses the number of trainees along the whole supply chain.

node.title: Social Security
node.description: Shows the level of living conditions and of social services that will be provided within community. The impact of a failed authorization: reduction or increase in life style-and general living standards for people that need social support.

node.title: R&D Expenditures
node.description: The internal and external expenditures of companies in research and development activities. This also relates to education and research, both of which serve to develop and maintain human capital.

node.title: Capital Investments
node.description: The definition covers the value of replacement and net investment, including general repair, purchase of concessions, patents and licenses.
